generation: Another week has flown by. Yesterday, I drove past the new house and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We might get the keys at closing—I’m getting really excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we should be set to close a week from Wednesday. Last night, Bethany and I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies. There’s been a lot of movie-watching happening lately. Here’s the rundown: last night, we watched *Thirteen*—a film every mother of a teenager should see. It was better than I expected. After that, we watched *Gigli*—and yes, it was just as bad as the reviews claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with reruns, but now there are two fantastic new shows I’ve been watching religiously for the past week. *Blow Out* has the gayest concept ever, yet somehow features zero gay people in sight. The show follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he attempts to open a second location of his wildly popular West Hollywood salon—this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care (least of all me), but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive, declaring (in his most theatrical voice), *"I am going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world—ever!"* And just like that, I was hooked. Not since *Rocco* have I found such a mesmerizingly clueless character so compelling to watch.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis, right under the shoulder blade. Whenever I move my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—the pain is unbearable. I’ve overdone it lately, updating my website and working on other online tasks, so now I can barely move it. Finding the energy to draw anything feels impossible, and the lack of sleep only makes the pain worse. I’m not in the best spirits right now, but I’ll recover.  

On a brighter note, my mom’s surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved slightly—she can now see blurry shapes and distinguish colors. Still, her vision remains severely impaired. Here’s hoping she regains it fully soon.

The kindness of strangers... Today, I attempted to do laundry with the kids in tow and realized how quickly even the simplest tasks can turn into an absolute ordeal. I also discovered just how unexpectedly sweet complete strangers can be—for no reason other than their own goodwill. Trust me, it wasn’t as if they had ulterior motives. I was covered in kid drool and sporting my "laundry day" attire... Besides, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive!  

Right now, I’m multitasking: composing this post while watching No Doubt’s greatest hits. Both activities are happening from the comfort of my desk in my room.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom repairing the personal computer of my workplace's personnel director. Not that I mind helping, but I sometimes wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to show care and support in this way, but where do you draw the line between helping and being taken advantage of?  

The past few weeks, I've been staying up late reading and such, so I was looking forward to turning in early—until I realized it made more sense to finish this repair and return the computer to its owner. *Laughs* No rest for the weary, right? So instead, I found myself rewatching *Joe Schmo 2* tonight.

Remind me—what was I writing about before this? Or rather, let’s continue the 'Is this a date?' saga. After that awkward lunch, my confidence was shaken, and I realized I left out a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started talking about what a great guy Pat is and how he’s trying to find him a girlfriend. I listened and nodded, slowly realizing the conversation was more about matchmaking for Dustin’s best friend than whatever small talk you’d normally have with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, stared into the mirror, and silently wondered: Am I being passed off to the other guy? Is this really happening?

I wish everyone would pause and reflect before acting. In fact, I’d love it if every single person in the world took a moment to think before getting out of bed each morning—and then made a conscious effort to keep thinking throughout the day. And if they’re unwilling to do even that, I’d strongly prefer they just stay in bed and slip into an endless sleep. I’ve had enough of mindless behavior. Now, I’m not claiming to be the sharpest tool in the shed—but I’m not talking about complex intellectual feats here, so I believe it’s fair to call out sheer stupidity. Let’s focus this rant on just a few specific types for now, and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

The scenario outlined in my previous post presents two key issues:  

1. While Bush is indeed stimulating the economy, his approach is misguided. As Robert Rubin noted on NPR's *Marketplace* today, the same economic stimulus could have been achieved without incurring long-term debt by implementing temporary tax cuts targeted at low- and middle-income earners. Ah, Robert Rubin—his very name carries a reassuring weight. Try naming a single domestic cabinet official in the Bush administration with Rubin's stature. Struggling? It might take a moment...  

2. Granting Republicans exclusive control during wartime is untenable, given their creation of an endless, global "War on Terror." Their strategy ensures perpetual conflict, making this concession unwise.

She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun" — The Offspring.  

Haven’t updated in a while, but there’s not much to say. Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as usual, and got to hang out with Tiago.  

On Saturday, I worked, then went out with Joe and Rach. Later met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Got home around 11:45 PM and woke up the next morning at 6:45 AM for a meet.  

Arrived a little late, but it was fine. I did my full floor routine without falling, placed second on floor and vault, and third on beam. Scored 29.45 all-around, which isn’t bad since my meets usually improve as the season progresses.

Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, utterly bored, and you begin to wonder what exactly happens in your brain that allows you to comprehend math? Then it dawns on you—you exist, you're in math class, and you question why. Suddenly, you're struck by how incredible existence is. And just as quickly, it hits you—the fact that you're spiraling into this random train of thought is downright pitiful. Ever experienced that? I despise it.  

You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who in their right mind thought that was a good idea? It’s obvious that enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is nothing short of cruel and unusual punishment.

I believe Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that cursed iron piece (not the hot one, but the game token) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by just a few dollars and won the frustrating game—or perhaps I let him win, considering he’s leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story unfolds, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I’m dealing with right now. I’ve taken some Aleve, and I must say it’s doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation.  

*Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck...* — At the Drive-In

Well… today has been a long day. We drove back home from Indiana, and I suppose I’ll need to be selective about what I write since I could easily go on for too long, and I’m just too tired. First, I have to say that camp was incredible—even better than I imagined. God has been working in my life so much lately, and it’s truly amazing. I feel like I’ve turned over a new leaf, but anyway, back to the start. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is the final day of my summer vacation—waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9, which I’m dreading, but I’d rather get it done now than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. Honestly, I’m a bundle of nerves—scared, jittery, and every other synonym for "absolutely not, I don’t want to go" when it comes to school.  

This is going to be an entirely new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling in everything I do, but starting something unfamiliar is tough. I despise feeling like a pawn (as I told Cassie: *"I’ll be the only pawn on the chessboard insisting on moving like a knight"*), and I can’t stand not knowing what’s coming next.

Suddenly, over the past two days, I’ve been overwhelmed by intense waves of exhaustion—utterly bone-deep fatigue. Yesterday evening, I went home and simply collapsed into sleep, only waking when my mother called me around eight-thirty. When I opened my eyes, the room was pitch black—I hadn’t turned on the lights—and for a few disoriented moments, I couldn’t tell the time or even the date. There was just my mother’s voice in the darkness and me struggling to grasp reality. I wonder why I’ve been feeling so drained…  

The weather was pleasant this morning—a light drizzle as I arrived. Though I hear it’s been raining nonstop in Calcutta for the past three days.

Last night was truly dreadful. I ended up discarding the sweater I’d been knitting, even though I’d already completed about 14 inches. It was a waste of roughly $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein), but by the time I reached the armholes, the stitch count was off, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked. Frogging—undoing rows—was nearly impossible because the yarn kept snapping. Oddly enough, I didn’t even curse, which is rare for me. Instead, I just gloomily unraveled it while binge-watching season two of *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, frustration won out, and I tossed it. I guess you could say I learned a lot from this sweater attempt.

Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading: *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter examines "implacement," while the second explores "displacement." In the opening chapter, Casey argues that contemporary culture prioritizes time as the central organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time," "saving time," or "just in time." He proposes, instead, that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded and connected community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates come across this post.) So far, this book is the first assigned reading that has truly captivated me.

Whatever they put in freeze pops to create those vibrant colors should come with a warning: may induce delightful absurdity. Laughter is welcome, of course—but would we have ended up on that fire escape, sipping beer in the howling wind, had we not eaten them earlier? Later, pausing in the doorway of a sadly shuttered bar, we flipped through an office-supplies catalog that had arrived in the mail. Thank goodness we did. Who could have predicted that its pages held the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. Just a few highlights: purchase 36 permanent markers, receive a stunt kite. This was a great weekend. I indulged in quite a bit of God’s green leaf, and after far too long, I finally listened to a lot of Nevermore—something I really should have started doing much sooner. I also read extensively, finishing three books over the weekend: Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*.  

*Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by global warming and societal collapse. While it was clever, well-paced, and thoroughly convincing, I have to admit that neither the story nor the characters left me with any profound impressions. That’s not to say they weren’t well-crafted or vividly portrayed—it’s a solid book, just not an exceptional one, in my opinion.

Because this is the aftermath—the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic, one only now coming to light. I was affected, but meeting with the course coordinator eventually allowed me to unburden myself, and in doing so, I’ve prevented another person from being stuck in such a pedagogically deficient practicum school.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the thirteenth time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I am math-phobic. You get the idea.  

As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and went to answer it. No one was there. Perfect.  

I returned to my studies and, just as a faint glimmer of understanding began to surface in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. *Bam*—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once more, no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

The past week has been utterly exhausting. From Tuesday through Thursday, I was busy completing the move to my new classroom. While the new space is larger and conveniently closer to my grade-level team—both important factors as I invest countless hours preparing for the year—I couldn’t help but wish I’d known about the move before the school year ended. Had I been aware, I would have discarded many of the unused books and supplies that ultimately came with me. Instead, this week was consumed by moving, unpacking, and aggressively purging unnecessary items. I’m incredibly grateful to my teammate Jill, who—despite still teaching in my old classroom this month—managed to move nearly my entire room for me with the help of her wonderful students!

You cannot escape it, nor deny it: a part of you will always dwell within me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never wed, even if we were never bound by title... I loved you deeply, and to this day, that feeling lingers like an echo in my heart. Forever, I will be haunted by the fleeting nights we shared—our hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a seaside evening... or a kiss beneath the rain. Whenever I feel the sharp sting of sorrow piercing my heart, you will be there. That fragment of you... still bleeding with the eternal love that once flourished within me... and endures. ... For her.

I feel uneasy. Investigative reporting strikes me as deeply problematic—or rather, the article I'm working on and its potential repercussions don’t sit well with me. Perhaps it’s because I lack conviction in it, unable to fully grasp its essence—the underlying urgency, the relentless drive to question. I was raised in a country where asking questions wasn’t just discouraged—it was dangerous. They’d shoot you for that. Lock you up under internal security laws. This freedom of speech, this open questioning—it’s unfamiliar to me. Admittedly, I’ve never been the easiest person to get along with.

Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I went on an outing to Guintubdan in La Carlota. For most of us, it was our first time visiting the place. We trekked to the waterfalls, which took about 30 minutes—a challenging hike that left us all catching our breath. But we made it! The water was icy cold, so chilly that it made our bodies go numb. We didn’t stay long, though, as we moved on to explore another nearby waterfall after less than an hour. Another half-hour trek awaited us, but the effort was worth it—the falls were serene, and the view was truly breathtaking. It felt like being one with nature, as if you could hear your own harmony with the surroundings. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, and the crisp air and icy streams were so soothing they could lull you to sleep.

Well, I’m sure my sisters are completely drunk by now. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters—when it’s time to drink, it’s time to drink. That’s one trait I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes: the desire to drink. There are very few occasions when I don’t mind having a drink, but let’s just say they’re exceptionally rare.  

We have one month left before Ed leaves, and I think it’s finally sinking in—for Ed and for all of us. Honestly, it sank in for me a long time ago. I just hope Ed will still be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring the swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit of it.

When he woke up on Sunday morning, he was thrilled to discover the Easter Bunny had visited. There’s truly nothing more heartwarming than seeing the joy on your child’s face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. While the Easter Bunny is fun, we always ensure our kids understand the true meaning of the holiday.

So when I come upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, like I just did moments ago, and they demand to know what’s wrong—honestly, how about just staying quiet? The GOP Faces Criticism Over Recruitment Tactics at Naturalization Ceremonies in Jacksonville  

Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are set to be relocated following complaints that GOP activists improperly registered new citizens as Republicans.  

By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy  

The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 individuals departing as newly minted Americans. However, just before the event concluded on June 29, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common practice at such ceremonies.  

This table, however, stood out: the volunteers distributing forms were Republican activists, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members.  

The situation raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who attended to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

As a non-American blogger, I’ve been somewhat hesitant to engage in certain discussions, especially those involving flags. But since I initiated the topic (the subject, not the flag-burning), I suppose I ought to weigh in. First, I believe the notion of criminalizing flag-burning is utterly absurd. Alright, I still haven’t seen what my blog will actually look like, but this seems like the right place to start. I’m not entirely sure what will unfold here—whether I’ll take to it or not—but since I spend so much time in front of a screen, I might as well put that time to good use and share all these scattered thoughts buzzing (or more accurately, stumbling) around in my head. Hey, so I watched *Troy* tonight with my family... and I wasn’t impressed. I’m too tired to go into detail, but I do think it had potential. However, it felt like too much effort went into the set (which was stunning) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. Urllink invites everyone to welcome the latest Atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene: Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, developed by Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This app appears to deliver a robust native experience. It’s worth noting that it isn’t free—a point of frequent discussion online. It sinks the ball in the net—or it gets the hose again. Absolutely incredible; I have no complaints about this game as it’s surpassed my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. Smooth movement, no bugs or crashes, plenty of story and content to keep you engaged, with daily options like multiple practices, events (including sponsorships), and even games. This review focuses solely on MyCareer mode, and so far, it’s a perfect 10/10. The face scan worked well for me (though my first attempt gave me an oddly shaped forehead—fixed on the second try). Magic fans, be warned... Wizards seems hesitant to create a truly engaging digital game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience—a game meant to be shared with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, playful banter, and game-changing plays. Unfortunately, Wizards of the Coast appears to have lost sight of this. If you opt to play with friends, you miss out on earning gold, which is crucial in-game. Gold is so vital that they’ve even imposed a daily cap—understandable, since it unlocks nearly everything. But brace yourself for a tedious, solitary grind in 1v1 matches against AI or silent strangers. If you’re playing for free, expect to spend roughly four hours daily for over a month, alone, just to unlock the cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, I’ll address the drawbacks first. I’ve never been fond of prequels, as they inherently move a story backward rather than forward—a common issue with the genre. That said, it does expand the narrative in meaningful ways. The combat lacks precision and feels less refined compared to the tight mechanics of *Arkham City*. At the time of writing this review (26/10/2013), there’s a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (though the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to awkward hotkeys, forcing your hand to stretch across the entire keyboard—a minor annoyance in theory, but one that can disrupt your combat flow and break combos.

They’ve effectively improved *Shadow Warrior (2013)*—the boss fights are fantastic, the weapons feel great (maybe not quite as refined as *DOOM 2016*'s, but still solid), and enemies aren’t overly tanky (unless you mishandle elemental and upgrade mechanics). The upgrade system is well-balanced and becomes intuitive without feeling tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo gently encourage experimenting with different weapons. There’s also a variety of genuinely unique weapons (a key distinction from *Borderlands*’ reliance on RNG-based loot) that remain useful throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is excellent, particularly the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush’s contributions.

So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know where to begin with this review. This all relates to my career mode. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard, standing at 1.71m, with maxed stats and all the necessary perks. Now, explain to me why shooting skill depends on a player’s height? Why can’t someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I’m 1.87m tall, so I initially created my player at this height—only to later discover I couldn’t exceed an 89 skill rating. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game warn me about this before I create my character, or even when I hit the skill cap after weeks of playing?!

I believe this Assassin's Creed installment perfected the mechanics across all aspects—ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, and more. I also felt a deeper connection to the protagonist. While the story begins somewhat uneven, it improves significantly as you progress (a trend I’ve noticed in most AC games). Edward was a compelling character, as were the supporting cast. The collectibles in this game felt more meaningful than in previous entries, perhaps because they served a greater purpose within the world. They weren’t mandatory, but they were enjoyable to pursue, offering well-balanced rewards.

While I personally can't recommend this game, it wasn't completely awful. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the funds to buy gun parts—which brings me to my primary criticism: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that aspect, the game would actually be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is a blast to use and HRV is a brilliant concept. I'd choose this over any Call of Duty title without hesitation, but its pay-to-win microtransaction system is a dealbreaker for me. If you're fine with this model, then by all means, enjoy it. But if you share my distaste for pay-to-win mechanics, it's best to pass—this one just isn't for us.

While not flawless, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can lead to occasional frustration—during my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a roughly 20-hour campaign, and I really wished for a reloadable save at that point. Since then, I’ve started using a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is a bit small, and the zoom feels underpowered.  

That said, it’s been an absolute blast. I’m not usually a fan of zombie games, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/brawler mechanics is fantastic. I’ve been playing whenever I can—always telling myself, "Just one more mission," or "One more supply run," or fleeing to safety before quitting. It’s hard to put down.

An absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame in the series (European Escalation and ALB), I can confidently say this one stands out. The sheer number of units is impressive—I’m not sure of the exact count, but there’s a ton! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box on the main menu is surprisingly entertaining—no joke. That said, if you think this game is 'easy' or you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared for a steep learning curve. Don’t get discouraged; you’ll lose plenty of units along the way. Just remember to plan ahead, always keep anti-air and anti-tank units ready, and you’ll get the hang of it.

I had a negative bias toward this game before playing it—I wasn’t even sure about buying it. For some reason, the whole portal gun and portal mechanics seemed odd to me, despite being a fan of science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s not cheesy (well, maybe a little at times). Each story character has their own distinct sense of humor, and they truly feel like unique personalities. And the level design? Absolutely brilliant. By the way, I never played the first *Portal* game, but I plan to someday if I find the time. Honestly, I wouldn’t have touched this sequel if I hadn’t played it first.

I encountered no performance issues even at launch, and with all the subsequent patches, the game now runs exceptionally well. In my opinion, it’s genuinely a fantastic and enjoyable game, though the format can be slightly frustrating at times—particularly how the free-roam city repopulates with enemies after each story progression. The 'dual play' segments, where you control Batman alongside another character, were a standout highlight. I also appreciated the flexibility of using a controller for most gameplay while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat sections. Navigating the Batmobile through the open city—especially during APC chases—becomes incredibly satisfying once you master using the brakes to drift around corners. Once you get the hang of it, cruising through Gotham is an absolute delight!

An absolutely outstanding FPS shooter—that sums it up perfectly. It looks, sounds, and plays brilliantly, with excellent mechanics, a compelling story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and an incredible soundtrack. That said, it’s not for the faint of heart—some cutscenes are brutally intense and graphic.  

When a game is this good, however, its flaws become more noticeable. Here’s what stood out to me:  
- No SLI support—seriously? I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my GPU, as performance was terrible on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. A solid single-GPU card is a must.  
- Frustratingly, even tiny obstacles are often impossible to climb.

English is not my native language—I am Dutch—so please excuse any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I’ll break down my thoughts into a few key categories:  

- **Graphics**  
- **Controls**  
- **Sound**  
- **Gameplay**  
- **Replayability**  

**Graphics:** The game features a comic-like art style. The visuals are sleek, avoiding unnecessary clutter, and the color schemes are well-chosen. This aesthetic perfectly suits the game. Even on higher settings, the graphics don’t strain your system. I run it on an Intel i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB RAM (Windows 8.1), and it performs flawlessly.  

**Controls:** The game supports both keyboard and mouse as well as an Xbox controller.

You can tell by the hours I’ve put into this game that I truly enjoy it. This is everything I hoped a tactical shooter from Call of Duty would be. However, don’t buy this game expecting it to play like COD, Battlefield, or any other mainstream shooter. It stands in a league of its own and should be appreciated as such. I can’t count how many times I’ve heard new players complain about dying too quickly. Seriously—god forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It’s not like that never happens in real life, right?  

Edit: Okay, so I’ve been playing this game for a while now and have invested quite a bit into it. It’s one of the best multiplayer experiences out there—perfect for when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and this game is killing me—in the best way possible. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, and the music is unexpectedly high-quality and perfectly fitting. The story and world have me hooked, and the puzzles are genuinely enjoyable. But what truly sets this game apart is its comedy. Whether you're a seasoned RPG player who'll appreciate the jokes, parodies, and references spanning the genre's history, or a newcomer who just enjoys great humor, this game delivers. If you've ever played *Final Fantasy VII* or *X*, this is a must-play—trust me, I had to pause after two hours just to let my cheeks recover from laughing and smiling so much. What an absolute delight so far.

I genuinely appreciate free-to-play games and indie developers, but unfortunately, this one didn’t resonate with me. While the concept seemed perfect for my tastes, the execution fell flat. As someone who enjoys puzzle and exploration games, I found this title unintuitive—even after consulting guides, the gameplay simply wasn’t engaging. The absence of a pause button (or its obscurity) feels like a significant flaw, especially given the timed sequences. Additionally, the experience leans heavily into cutscenes, leaving me waiting more than playing.

This game... wow, where do I even begin? It was absolutely stunning, from the story to the graphics—I was completely hooked. The narrative wasn’t just a story; it felt like I *was* the protagonist, unraveling each twist as my character lived it. The gameplay was fantastic, and I even discovered things about myself along the way (like my previously unknown fear of heights, thanks to the ice caverns). My stomach was in knots the entire time, but I pushed through—for Uncle Fred! If you ever release a DLC or sequel, I’d be the first in line to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. To everyone involved in creating this masterpiece: thank you. You crafted something truly beautiful.

*Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth* is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization toward a specific goal or "victory." Unlike previous entries in the series, which followed Earth's historical timeline—spanning eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age—this installment takes place in the future, tasking players with colonizing a new planet.  

What I appreciate about this game is how 2K introduced fresh mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer, offering a unique twist on the classic formula. However, these additions can occasionally feel overwhelming.  

One area I believe could be improved is the artwork—particularly the environments seen during leader interactions, which could benefit from more visual variety and polish.

Great game! It offers tons of replayability and delivers a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely ranks in my top five zombie games of all time.  

**Edit:** After playing for 60+ hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games out there. It’s designed like a survival horror—you need to conserve ammo, treat your wounds when bleeding, take pills for infections, and more.  

The zombies feel surprisingly natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play title.  

*P.S.:* I’d recommend playing with one or two friends, but the community is incredibly friendly. You can easily make new friends or chat with others via text or voice comms.

Very late last night, I finally finished this. While the story itself isn’t particularly deep or compelling, its storytelling truly sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly immersive, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of expanding the world. I learned a great deal about Batman’s universe, though it was a bit disappointing how few boss fights the game included. Still, future installments can easily address that. The combat strikes a good balance in difficulty, leaning slightly toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman didn’t feel especially rewarding, but upgrading and unlocking gadgets throughout the campaign introduced enjoyable new mechanics. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas provided a satisfying sense of progression.

To the Moon" is no ordinary game—far from it. It is a profound experience, and one of the finest I’ve ever had. You think Telltale’s *The Walking Dead* is sad? Well, it doesn’t even come close to *To the Moon*! Never before has something purely fictional left me so deeply moved yet strangely fulfilled. This masterpiece stands, in my opinion, as the pinnacle of storytelling, complemented by a soundtrack that is utterly charming and flawless.  

Admittedly, the controls can feel a bit clunky, and gameplay isn’t its strongest suit—but the story is so extraordinary that none of that mattered to me in the slightest. The humor, too, is brilliantly woven in, never detracting from the story’s emotional weight. And, of course, the endless *Doctor Who* references are just the icing on the cake.

Bastion is an outstanding game, featuring a truly captivating storyline. Set in the aftermath of a catastrophic event, your journey revolves around rebuilding the world from the bastion. The game offers a wealth of choices, from deciding which structures to construct for strategic benefits, to selecting weapons, customizing them with power-ups, and choosing drinks that grant bonus effects. The art style and soundtrack are exceptional, with vibrant visuals that prove the apocalypse doesn’t have to be bleak. One of its finest features is the dynamic narration, which reacts to your actions—whether you pick up a weapon or swap it in the armory, the narrator seamlessly comments on your decisions, adding depth to the experience.

I originally purchased this game during its early development phase, back when the only currency was SpaceBux and there was no 'tech tree' to speak of. That was when the game was at its best. At that time, all the guns were equally overpowered, so balance wasn't an issue—everyone could take down anyone at any moment.  

The game also used to grant unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd think that for a title boasting 'bajillions of guns,' they'd offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before locking the rest behind a paywall. At one point, I had around three pages' worth of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for even more because, for me, that was where the real fun lay.

This game turned out to be a delightful surprise. While glowing reviews for products can often be misleading, in this case, they truly captured the enjoyment of this clever little game. It blends a classic 2D platformer with MOBA elements in a stylish and unique way. I unexpectedly found myself drawn to characters I wouldn’t typically enjoy in other MOBAs. Though I initially hesitated, I decided to try a melee tank—and was pleasantly surprised by how much fun it was, leading me to experiment with more characters as they unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface have a quirky charm, so much so that I’ve adopted one of the characters as my avatar and even use a wallpaper from the game’s card set creator.

I just started playing, but I already love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has captivated me like this. The music sets the perfect mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every combat encounter—they've optimized the battles exceptionally well. I initially had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly satisfying to decimate multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose is by failing to retreat. If the fight seems overwhelming, just withdraw, regroup, and strike back. Thank you, devs, for this incredible experience!

The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, especially for its protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may initially resist these alterations to their beloved character, the improvements are undeniable—and Ninja Theory’s new game demonstrates this masterfully. *DmC* offers the ideal entry point for newcomers, tracing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and documenting his transformation from self-interest to selflessness. The game crafts a clear, engaging narrative arc for this reimagined Dante, making him a captivating figure to follow. The story unfolds as Dante is thrust into the corrupt world he once deliberately turned away from.

Where do I even begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with meticulous detail, and brimming with joy—bad puns, pesky dogs, and hidden secrets included. It knows when to be serious but never shies away from humor. The character design is impeccable, featuring a diverse cast with unique personalities and intriguing backstories. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its rare approach: you don’t have to kill anyone, a refreshing twist in the genre. Drawing heavy inspiration from *EarthBound*, one of the finest RPGs I’ve ever played, its quality is undeniable. And the soundtrack? Easily the best I’ve heard in years.

I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more 'enjoyable' experience for some. Personally, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half of the narrative relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor emotionally affected—perhaps I’m desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to evoke a reaction. The other half attempts to depict mental decline, exploring themes like obsession, hallucination, and depression. In concept, it’s an interesting idea. However, the 'game' took me just 10 minutes to finish, even while carefully reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why *Portal* is amazing? It's a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you run with it. This brilliant approach challenges your mind while keeping the experience enjoyable. Though not heavily story-driven, it spawned one of the most beloved and popular games of 2011. I still revisit this game when I'm bored, completing it time and again—returning to witness the origins of a legend and the legend itself.  

**Gameplay**: *Portal*'s mechanics are deceptively simple to describe. You manipulate portals to solve puzzles, aided by buttons that trigger parts of the environment. There are two types: one you press directly and another that requires placing a weighted cube on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two—one minor and the other quite annoying—*edit: both have since been resolved, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120*) and are looking for a space exploration game, I can wholeheartedly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine:  

- **CPU:** i5 6600k (~€200)  
- **GPU:** Radeon RX 480 (~€200)  
- **Motherboard:** Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150)  
- **RAM:** 16GB DDR4 (~€70)  

Totaling around €650, this setup falls squarely in the mid-range price bracket—though admittedly, it’s fairly new. I maintain a near-constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. Frankly, I’m baffled by the 90% of comments claiming their overkill rigs struggle to hit 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it’s been that long since we’ve seen an RTS game of such high quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to being one of my personal favorites in the genre. Combine that with a grand strategy mode reminiscent of Risk, and it truly hits the mark. I’ll admit—I try not to be overly biased—but the fact that this game lets you transform into a dragon, supporting your troops, attacking enemies, and even managing unit production and deployment simultaneously is hard to ignore.  

These days, I do appreciate complex RTS games like Civ V and others. However, many of them tend to cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resource systems into a single overwhelming experience.

*Undertale* blends its elements into something far greater than their individual parts. The graphics hold up well for a retro-style game, and the soundtrack is pleasant, but when combined, they create moments of genuine beauty and emotional impact. The writing spans a wide range—from comedy to drama, heartbreak to hope, often simultaneously—all while subverting classic RPG tropes. And that’s without even delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could go on for pages. But instead, I’ll keep it simple: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you love video games, play this game. If you have even a few spare hours in your lifetime, play this game.

I've only owned this game for a few months, yet in that brief period, two DLCs have already been released alongside patches that transformed an already outstanding game into something truly exceptional. The developers are highly engaged with the community, evident through their active presence in discussion forums and detailed dev diaries. While the game's mechanics present a reasonably steep learning curve—one I'm still mastering—this depth of strategy offers countless approaches to achieving objectives and capitalizing on opportunities. In my opinion, the game boasts near-endless replayability. Every session draws me in completely, regardless of how my current playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of gameplay. However, after that brief period of fun, you'll quickly notice that the game largely revolves around repetitive combat, enemies, and mechanics. The standout positive aspect is the developers' dedication—they release semi-frequent updates that often introduce substantial content, ranging from major system overhauls to new Warframes and various tweaks or features. It's a solid choice for casual play, though it's unlikely to hold your interest for more than a few months unless you genuinely enjoy grinding. The best part? It's free, so I’d still recommend giving it a try. If you're after a quick gaming fix, go ahead and dive in.

This game is... incredibly dull. I purchased it thinking it would be a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a beloved and charming PS2 title. Unfortunately, it falls far short. The core mechanic involves growing larger by absorbing progressively bigger objects, but the gameplay feels clunky, the levels lack creativity, and the overall tone is a surreal horror experience—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you feeling bleak and questioning existence. Every "living" creature in this game, from tiny pets to humans, makes me suspect the developers had an unsettling fascination with taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was genuinely excited when I first heard about this game. I thought, *Wow! A simulator about the journey to becoming president? That sounds amazing!* Well, it really wasn’t.  

The game starts by forcing you to pick a side—Republican or Democrat—with no option for an independent or third-party candidate. That was a bit disappointing, but I stayed optimistic to see what else it had to offer.  

I will give the game some credit: the character customization, though limited, is pretty fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you get the choice to wear your head—or not—during a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3 had a superior story. The settlement system disrupts the narrative so much that managing them feels like tedious babysitting rather than enjoying the main plot. Certain keys are hardcoded and can't be remapped. The game is riddled with bugs—at one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to dig through console commands to restore it. Power armor lacks the prestige of earlier games; it's handed to you almost immediately, and fusion cores are overly abundant in shops. The story is mediocre, and while the game is more stable than Fallout 3 (which crashed constantly), it still falls short. It doesn't surpass Fallout 3 or New Vegas. Despite the hype, this installment disappoints in nearly every aspect.

The game is delightfully entertaining, and progressing through it is genuinely enjoyable. ^_^ However, it can get a bit frustrating if you aim to collect every cube and unlock all achievements. I can easily understand why others enjoy this game, but it just wasn’t for me. For one, I own a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Beyond that, while the game’s vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its sheer scale to be more of a hindrance than a benefit. The steep learning curve and the time required to reach anything engaging early on were simply too much for me. Without a doubt, this is my all-time favorite first-person shooter. It’s not for run-and-gun Rambo types. The recoil and ballistics are incredibly realistic—rifle-caliber shots to the chest, neck, or head are almost always fatal unless they barely graze you. Bullets drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are essential for staying on target. There’s no unlimited ammo here; if you constantly reload mid-magazine, you’ll end up with a pouch full of half-empty clips. Stamina matters too—sprint too long, and your aim wavers as you struggle to catch your breath. For steadier shots, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a window ledge. Standing shots? Expect less accuracy.

Let me begin by saying I didn’t purchase *XCOM: Enemy Unknown* when it first released—I bought it later on sale, which included *Enemy Within*, so I never encountered the issues some players reported. That said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game. It was challenging early on but incredibly rewarding when executed well.  

As for *XCOM 2*, I’m loving it. The game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, even with a GTX 560 (2GB VRAM). Initially, it defaulted to high settings and had some minor sluggishness, though still playable. Switching to medium improved performance noticeably.  

I’m not sure if I’ve just been fortunate with game performance, but many negative reviews come across as overly entitled to me.

+ RPG leveling  
+ Wide variety of ship types  
+ Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles  
+ Easy-to-learn resource management  
+ Dark humor  
- Grind-heavy (if not utilizing civilian stations effectively)  
- Subpar AI teammates  
- Limited equipment variety

Listen, this game is an absolute blast. Despite the drawbacks I mentioned, there's still plenty of variety and strategic depth. It kicks off fast and only gets more intense. Even with the limited equipment options, there’s always a new ship to unlock or skill to upgrade. To really extend the game’s lifespan, mods are the way to go—*Fight for Universe* is the standout, but *Big Fight for Beef* is also excellent.

World leaders convene to address global uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the world arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will deliberate on pressing issues spanning China's economic influence to Iraq's post-election future following this Sunday's polls. Among the attendees are UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, joining more than 20 other heads of state and government leaders.  

Unlike in past years, protests against the WEF are anticipated to be subdued, with anti-globalization activists canceling a planned weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, deliberately scheduled to coincide with the WEF's more exclusive gathering in Davos.

The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal is approaching, with Fiat and General Motors (GM) having until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. This deadline signifies the point at which Fiat gains the right to sell its automotive division to GM, as stipulated in their 2000 alliance agreement. GM, facing financial losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to retain the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday fueled by hopes of a settlement. The US automaker is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to exit the arrangement. GM contends that the deal was invalidated when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM's stake through a capital increase. The original 2000 agreement emerged from a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions spent on conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to alleviate poverty. He made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his position during his Christmas Midnight Mass.  

In his Christmas message, the Cardinal denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" misuse of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly opposed the conflict. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4’s *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that vast sums had been devoted to warfare rather than lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The Cardinal urged that 2005 should be a year dedicated to the campaign to "make poverty history.

Renowned screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, celebrated for her contributions to the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film starring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter hunted by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the movie grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for independent cinema at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*.  

A New Jersey native, Hill started her career as a production assistant and steadily rose through the ranks, serving as an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Widely regarded as a trailblazer for women in film, she took on roles in the 1970s that were predominantly held by men, leaving a lasting legacy in the industry.

Broadband is accelerating online expression, as fast internet access inspires more individuals to share their thoughts and creations online, according to research. A study by UK think tank Demos reveals that a quarter of broadband users in Britain frequently upload content and maintain personal websites. The report highlights that constant, high-speed connectivity is transforming how people engage with the internet. With over five million UK households now on broadband—a figure rapidly increasing—the study examined its influence on online behavior. Findings show that more than half of broadband users access the web before breakfast, while one in five confesses to waking up at night to browse. Most notably, the report suggests broadband is empowering users to participate more actively in the digital space.

Yukos Returns to US Courts  

The Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it persists in its battle for survival. The company is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt.  

Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, aiming to leverage international business law to prevent the forced sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was ultimately sold for $9.4 billion to state-owned oil firm Rosneft, though only after disruptions during the state auction.  

Yukos’ legal team now contends that the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue any firms acquiring its assets, employing every available legal recourse.

Voters are flocking to the Blog Awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, honoring the best web blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were unveiled on Sunday, but the surge in traffic to the official site was so overwhelming that it temporarily crashed due to excessive visitors. Weblogs have earned nominations across 30 categories, ranging from top regional blogs to the best-kept-secret blogs.  

Blogs had a monumental year, with a leading U.S. dictionary declaring "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new ones are created daily. According to the U.S. research think tank Pew Internet and American Life, a new blog emerges every 5.8 seconds—yet fewer than 40% of all blogs are updated at least once every two months.

A documentary offering an intimate glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will be featured in the festival's Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film captures the singer reflecting on both his professional journey and personal experiences—from his early days in Wham! to more recent chapters of his life. Michael himself will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into Michael's rise with Wham!, his solo career, his legal disputes with record label Sony, and his vocal opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

For the first time, digital music downloads are being integrated into the main US singles chart. Billboard’s Hot 100 now includes data from digital download sales, which were previously limited to a separate download chart. Green Day’s *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* currently holds the number two spot on Billboard’s Pop Chart while leading its digital chart.  

The UK singles chart is also set to incorporate download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard’s Hot Digital Sales chart, but they will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the updated Hot 100.  

Additionally, Billboard’s second new chart—the Pop 100—merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts its airplay data to US radio stations that feature chart music.

Anti-spam laws have dealt a heavy blow to a notorious spammer, as the self-proclaimed "spam king" of the internet seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the operator behind OptInRealBig.com and the source of billions of junk emails, claims lawsuits have driven his company to file for Chapter 11. OptInRealBig faces multiple legal challenges, most significantly from Microsoft, which is pursuing millions in damages. The company stated that the bankruptcy filing would allow it to address its legal issues while continuing operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by anti-spam watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws with its mass email campaigns. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer led the lawsuit, alleging Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages using 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied reports of a rift with former coach Jacques Santini, insisting Santini's resignation was due solely to personal reasons. Recent newspaper speculation suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's influence at White Hart Lane.  

"These claims are completely untrue," Arnesen stated in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live. "Only one factor led to his resignation—his own personal issues. He has spoken to me recently and confirmed this matter was entirely his own."  

Arnesen admitted he could not elaborate on the specific reasons behind Santini's abrupt departure after just 13 matches in charge. "Jacques never disclosed the exact details, but I trust his word on this. We must accept and respect his decision," he added.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with a commanding victory at Murrayfield. Economic Focus for Election Battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. Brizzell to compete in AAA's in Sheffield  
Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzell will be among eight of Ireland’s European Indoor hopefuls taking part in this weekend’s AAA Championships. US-based athletes Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish competitors selected so far for the Europeans who will not race in Sheffield.  

Brizzell will defend his 200m title at the British trials, while in-form James McIlroy aims to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m event. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the Tri-Nations final.

England have the opportunity to secure their third consecutive autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, while also avenging their 51-15 defeat by Australia in June. Iraq to Invite Bids for Phone Licenses  

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications stated that bids will be open to local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning firms will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed-line network, delivering voice, fax, and internet services.  

The ministry emphasized its goal to raise Iraq's "currently low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within ten years." Additionally, it aims to develop a "dynamic and adaptable telecommunications sector."  

Details of the bidding and tender process will be announced on the ministry's website on February 9. A roadshow for potential investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

A growing number of older adults and women are taking the lead in safeguarding home computers against online threats, reveals a two-year study. Between 2002 and 2004, purchases of antivirus, anti-spam, and anti-spyware programs by women increased by 11.2% annually. Conducted for the cybersecurity firm Preventon, the research demonstrates that security awareness is spreading across diverse internet users.  

Notably, retirees account for 40% of home cybersecurity software buyers, with this figure rising by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Among retirees, women (53%) outpace men in adopting protective measures. These findings highlight shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, as well as heightened recognition of the risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts signal the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or similar digital music player can store up to 10,000 songs—ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod users are populating that space with audio content produced by a diverse range of creators. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," championed most notably by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Though the term derives from the Apple iPod, an iPod isn’t necessary to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, typically produced by individuals from their homes. All that’s required is a microphone, a computer, and basic editing software. Once created, these shows are uploaded to the internet, where anyone can download and enjoy them—completely free of charge.

Levy wins Whitbread Novel Prize  
Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book *Small Island*. She now emerges as the frontrunner for the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst’s *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean secured the Children’s Fiction Award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*.  

All category winners will advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A judging panel featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement following later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned London-based Levy’s novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos is pursuing legal action to challenge the sale of its main asset and will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm behind the purchase. Yukos has announced its intention to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the $20 billion sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. The company's U.S. legal team will also seek to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a U.S. court order last week that attempted to halt the sale.  

The origins of Baikal and its motives for acquiring the unit remain uncertain. Russian media reports suggest that Baikal—which secured Yuganskneftegas for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) in a state-backed auction on Sunday—has close ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia’s fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, sealing the win with two early goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the first minute, rising to meet Jamie McAllister's free-kick and looping a header over Colin Meldrum from 10 yards out. McAllister then doubled the lead, arriving at the back post to nod home Saul Mikoliunas' cross, putting the game out of Livingston's reach. Craig Easton pulled one back with a contentious header after an hour, but Hearts stood firm.  

The breakthrough came after Gus Bahoken's clumsy challenge on Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister delivered a precise free-kick into the box, where Miller outjumped Livingston's static defense to direct his header over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes in, Hearts extended their advantage when Mikoliunas surged down the right flank and delivered a cross to the far post, where McAllister arrived to power his header past the keeper.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables customers in need of substantial computing power to rent it by the hour. Dubbed Sun Grid, the service charges users $1 (53p) per hour for access to processing and storage capabilities on Sun-maintained systems. Grid computing, the latest industry buzzword, reflects Sun's belief that computing capacity is as vital a commodity as hardware and software. The company draws a parallel between grid computing and the evolution of electricity, suggesting the system could mature similarly to utilities like power and water.  

"Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" remarked Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz during a webcast announcing the company's quarterly network computing event in California.

Scotland's Justice Minister Cathy Jamieson has issued a stern warning to bigoted football fans, stating she intends to target them "where it hurts most" by imposing match bans. Jamieson highlighted exclusion orders as one of several measures under consideration in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism.  

She commended both Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue but emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a top priority. Jamieson made these remarks ahead of Sunday's third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead.  

The long-standing sectarianism associated with segments of both clubs' fanbases has become a major focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from Celtic and Rangers to discuss the ongoing problem.

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the UK debut of the new film *Beyond the Sea* at its British premiere in London’s Leicester Square on Thursday. Home phones face an uncertain future, as the traditional fixed-line telephone in households may soon become a rarity. Research conducted by handset manufacturer Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people rely solely on their mobile phones for all calls, whether making or receiving them. The study indicates that over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobile devices. While some retain fixed-line phones due to lower call costs, the majority of respondents agreed that the future undoubtedly lies with mobile technology.  

The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted distinct usage patterns between mobile and landline phones. Fixed-line phones were preferred for longer conversations, whereas mobile calls tended to be shorter, often between mobile users or with friends. In the UK, 69% of participants cited cost savings as the primary reason for still using a landline, acknowledging that it remains cheaper than mobile alternatives.

Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a decisive defeat against Jurgen Melzer in the SAP Open quarter-finals.
