A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party coalition unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, with 70% of its members elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have struggled to reach consensus on reform. The group claims it can secure support to remove the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government previously delayed plans to eliminate hereditary peers, citing insufficient support due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. There are indications that Labour's manifesto may include proposals to alter at least the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott remains confident of securing a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships despite a slightly disappointing debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid.  

"It was certainly a learning experience, and I still believe I can challenge for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete.  

The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record, followed by Sweden’s Robert Kronberg in second and Haiti’s Dudley Dorival in third.  

Scott, who won his heat in 7.64 seconds, expressed mild frustration with his performance in the final, where he ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A U.S. woman has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are covertly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed plaintiff from Georgia claims that an embedded chip in the cartridge falsely signals the printer to prompt a refill even when ink remains. The class-action lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. consumers who purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's leading printer manufacturer, has declined to comment on the ongoing litigation. While HP's cartridges utilize chip technology to monitor ink levels and alert users when replacement is needed, the lawsuit asserts that these chips also deactivate the cartridges by a preset deadline, irrespective of remaining ink.

Virgin Radio is set to pioneer 3G broadcasting in the UK, becoming the first station worldwide to deliver radio via 3G mobile networks. In collaboration with technology partner Sydus, the station will transmit on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download dedicated software from Virgin Radio's website to access the service.  

James Cridland, Virgin Radio's Head of New Media, remarked, 'This innovation positions radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution.' Virgin Radio will lead the rollout, followed by its digital counterparts, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove.  

Cridland added, 'This application ensures seamless access to Virgin Radio anytime, anywhere—all you need is the phone in your pocket.'

Roxy Music has been announced for the lineup of June's Isle of Wight Festival, joining Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as the headliners for the three-day event, running from 10-12 June. Original members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the festival's Saturday night. The band is also currently recording new material in the studio—their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year, Roxy Music first rose to fame with their 1972 hit *Virginia Plain*. Other notable tracks include *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's *Jealous Guy*.

The captains are lining up for the Aid Match, with Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll among four Six Nations skippers selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid Match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami have also been named in the Northern squad. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere side in this Tsunami relief fundraiser at Twickenham.  

"I’m excited to work with such exceptional players," Woodward remarked. The match will also serve as an opportunity for him to evaluate potential candidates before finalizing his British and Irish Lions touring squad for their summer tour to New Zealand.  

"This game is set to be a fantastic spectacle," he added.

The comedy *Sideways* triumphed at this year's Independent Spirit Awards, sweeping all six categories for which it was nominated. The film claimed Best Feature, while Alexander Payne earned Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the latter honor with co-writer Jim Taylor. The cast also shone, with Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen each securing acting awards. *Sideways*, a strong contender at Sunday’s Oscars with five nominations, continued its award-season momentum.  

Now in their 20th year, the Spirit Awards celebrate films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Among other winners, Catalina Sandino Moreno claimed Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*—a role that also earned her an Oscar nomination. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for the same film.

Prince was crowned the "top music earner" of 2004, surpassing renowned artists like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual ranking. The iconic singer amassed $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concert revenues, album sales, and publishing royalties, driven by his successful *Musicology* tour and album release. Madonna secured second place with earnings of $54.9 million (£29.5 million) during her *Re-Invention* world tour. Meanwhile, veteran duo Simon & Garfunkel claimed 10th place, generating $24.9 million (£13.4 million) from their much-anticipated comeback tour.  

*Rolling Stone* noted, "Prince reclaimed the spotlight after a decade on the commercial sidelines." His 2004 tour alone grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and his latest album, *Musicology*, sold an impressive 1.9 million copies.

Walmart pushes back against critics as two major U.S. corporations launch advertising campaigns to clarify their positions on products and corporate practices. The global retail giant Walmart placed over 100 full-page advertisements in national newspapers, aiming to counter criticism regarding its compensation policies, employee benefits, and promotion strategies. Simultaneously, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is preparing a campaign to address what it calls "misleading" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart initiated its response with ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott, who stated it was time for the public to hear the "unvarnished truth." "There are many 'urban myths' circulating about Walmart," he wrote, "but facts remain facts.

The Conservatives have outlined policing plans under which local communities would vote to elect their own area's police commissioner. Party leader Michael Howard stated that this new role would replace what he called "inconspicuous" police authorities, while clarifying that the position would not override the authority of chief constables.  

The Liberal Democrats raised concerns that the proposal could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour dismissed the Tories' promises on policing as "extravagant."  

In response, Jan Berry, Chair of the Police Federation of England and Wales—which represents rank-and-file officers—stressed the importance of maintaining operational independence. "Policing is a public service, not a political football to be kicked around every election cycle," she said. "These plans risk enabling individuals with extreme political views to dictate operational decisions on the ground," Berry warned.

At a glance: Tory health checks  
The UK's opposition Conservative Party has announced plans to implement mandatory health screenings for immigrants if they win the upcoming general election. Here’s an overview of the proposal:  

- Individuals relocating to Britain from outside the EU for work or residence would be subject to health checks.  
- Those intending to stay for six months or longer, originating from countries with high tuberculosis (TB) rates, would require a chest X-ray and additional tests if necessary.  
- All non-EU nationals seeking to remain in the UK for a year or more would undergo a comprehensive medical examination, covering conditions such as tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV.  
- A positive TB test would result in an automatic visa rejection.  
- Other medical conditions would be assessed individually on a case-by-case basis.

Paris Promise Lifts Welsh Hopes: Was there ever a more thrilling Six Nations match than Saturday's epic showdown in Paris? And can Wales' resurgence carry them all the way to their first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the questions captivating not only Welsh supporters but rugby enthusiasts worldwide after an electrifying performance in the French capital.  

Welsh icon Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning teams in the 1970s, praised it as "one of the finest displays of the last thirty years." Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales that day, described it as "one of the most surreal matches I’ve ever been part of." Meanwhile, a dejected French coach, Bernard Laporte, remarked simply: "There was a French half—and there was a Welsh half."

Doves have soared to the top of the UK album charts with their latest release, *Some Cities*. The Manchester rock trio has displaced the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters from the number one spot. Their album follows the success of the single *Black and White Town*, which peaked at number six.  

Meanwhile, R&B star Nelly claims the top spot on the singles chart with *Over and Over*, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. The top ten also features new entries from Girls Aloud, Akon, Kaiser Chiefs, Futureheads, and Usher.  

Elvis Presley’s latest re-release, *(Marie’s the Name) His Latest Flame*, debuts at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud’s *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop artist Akon’s *Locked Up* holds strong at number five, while the highly acclaimed Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs secure their second chart hit at number six with *Oh My God*.

Mefin Davies, the Wales hooker, is expected to remain with Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales has learned that while the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, Davies prefers to stay with his current club. A standout performer in Wales' recent RBS Six Nations victory over England, Davies is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, his contributions to the Zurich Premiership side have been significant, making a new deal likely next season.  

Davies found himself without a regional team following the disbandment of the Celtic Warriors, leading him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he later featured for the Ospreys at the request of Wales management, he expressed frustration over his treatment before ultimately securing his move to Gloucester.

Cabinet frustration over Brown's funding shift has been acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford, as ministers express discontent over plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown redirected £512 million from central to local government budgets. Raynsford revealed having held "frank and robust discussions" with colleagues regarding the proposal. However, he emphasized that local governments must maintain quality services without imposing significant tax increases.  

The central government allocation forms part of a £1 billion package aimed at helping English local authorities limit next year's council tax rises to under 5%—a critical consideration in what is expected to be a general election year. Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in ensuring efficiently managed local authorities.

The Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is turning to Africa, with four African players—including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro—set to feature for the team in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab side to compete in European football, will face English Premier League outfit Newcastle United in the first round.  

Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a key role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. The goalkeeper recently joined the Israeli club after a short spell with South Africa's Hellenic.  

Last season, Bnei Sakhnin clinched the Israeli Cup and are based in Sakhnin, a town near Haifa. Known for their strong values, the club is a prominent advocate for peace and cooperation within Israel.

Stricter Drink-Drive Limit Could Save More Lives Than Expected"  

A new report suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save significantly more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the legal limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would prevent 65 fatalities annually.  

The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs preparing to vote on the government’s Road Safety Bill. While the bill proposes changes to speeding penalties, it does not address the drink-drive limit.  

According to transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, who led the study, implementing the lower limit would also result in 230 fewer serious road injuries compared to 2003 levels, saving the UK approximately £119 million per year. This contrasts with a 1998 Department of Transport estimate, which projected only 50 lives saved annually under similar measures.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. The system employs a 1×1 μm² diode to measure energy deposition by individual charged particles within the depletion region, while the array configuration offers an expansive detection area of 512×512 μm². Rather than detecting voltage fluctuations induced by radiation, the proposed system quantifies pulse width—the duration required for the voltage to stabilize back to baseline—eliminating the need for bulky, power-intensive analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated using TSMC's 65 nm LP CMOS process, demonstrates an average static power consumption of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's full functionality has been successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam environment.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the adverse effects of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the presumption that AVs would willingly submit to external control by a central authority is impractical. This paper introduces a combined routing and pricing control framework designed to incentivize AVs to adopt centrally coordinated system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium (UE)-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) incur congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization model, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level consists of a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for mixed fleets of AVs and HVs under equilibrium conditions.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled motional states. Beyond pushing larger, more tangible objects into the quantum regime, this advancement has spurred proposals to utilize mechanical oscillators for quantum information processing, communication, and high-precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a wider range of quantum motional states, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals highlighted the potential to overcome this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. While experimental realizations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have yet to achieve nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer valuable product assessments to guide customer decisions. However, these evaluations can be compromised by fake reviews ("spams") created by professional spammers, who continually refine increasingly subtle and effective spamming tactics to evade detection systems. Capturing spamming strategies is challenging, as they evolve rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and—most critically—often remain undiscovered. Moreover, current detectors primarily emphasize detection accuracy, which does not fully align with preserving the reliability of product evaluations. To tackle these issues, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and detectors compete based on practical objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield robust detectors that remain effective against any mixed detection strategies.

We designed single-shot shaped pulses to achieve ultra-high-fidelity (UH-fidelity) population transfer in a three-level quantum system with a lambda configuration. To guarantee high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions that enable exact transfer, where each solution adheres to a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identified a tracking solution featuring a single adjustable parameter to simultaneously control the transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We quantified robustness for UH-fidelity transfers by measuring the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which the infidelity exceeds \(10^{-4}\). Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses, particularly for moderate pulse areas.

In this work, we investigate the optimization landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Despite the inherent nonconvexity, which gives rise to multiple local minima that may not be globally optimal—even in well-separated mixtures—we demonstrate that all local minima exhibit a consistent structural pattern. This structure partially identifies the true component centers, as each local minimum either assigns multiple fitted Gaussians to a single true component or fits a single Gaussian to multiple true components, without overlap. Our analysis holds under a specific separation condition for the true mixture components and remains applicable whether the number of components is correctly specified, overestimated, or underestimated. For three-component Gaussian mixtures, we derive more precise results that explicitly characterize the dependence on the separation between components.

We examine the relationship between two distinct approaches for constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold arises as a quotient by an appropriate subgroup \( G \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( X_m \) in a weighted projective space, defined by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( W_m \).  

The first method, known as the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs a different weighted projective space and involves taking the quotient of a new hypersurface \( X_{m^t} \) within it by a dual group \( G^t \).  

The second approach, Batyrev's construction, derives the mirror partner as a hypersurface in a toric variety associated with the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope corresponding to the original Calabi-Yau orbifold.  

We present a straightforward argument supporting the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this study, we present a generalized approach to human gait analysis, building upon existing models from the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model integrates a metabolic energy minimization strategy during race processes with a nonlinear description of the mass center's libration movement, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition behavior. Experimental results across various speed regimes demonstrate that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center serves as a significant parameter in quantifying this dynamic. The experimental protocol was implemented in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences department, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce a novel mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator designed for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. This method employs a time regularization technique that preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while dynamically reducing the effective step size during planetary close approaches. By utilizing a high-order MVS scheme, the algorithm maintains efficiency with large time steps in regions devoid of close encounters. We demonstrate that this approach can accurately resolve near-collisions (with separations as small as a fraction of a planetary radius) while employing the same time-step used for weakly perturbed systems, such as the Solar System. The long-term stability of the method is validated through simulations of six super-Earths undergoing strong gravitational scattering over 50 kyr. Comparisons with hybrid methods like Mercury reveal superior energy conservation at comparable computational cost.

Entanglement serves as a fundamental resource in quantum information processing. A commonly employed method for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator yields non-negative results for all separable states but may produce negative values for certain entangled states. In practice, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging due to the exponential growth of the Hilbert-space dimension with increasing system size. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme necessitates $n+1$ local measurement settings and can withstand up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and remains effective for white noise levels up to $1/3$.

Within the framework of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime stands as the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We present a generalized approach to derive the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply this method to an extensive class of horizonless microstate geometries. Unlike the Kerr metric, these geometries may violate axial and equatorial symmetry, exhibiting a far more intricate multipolar structure—thereby offering a phenomenological avenue to constrain fuzzball models. Our numerical analysis suggests that, in absolute terms, all multipole moments typically exceed those of a Kerr black hole with equivalent mass and spin. Present measurements of the quadrupole moment in black-hole candidates impose only weak constraints on fuzzball scenarios, whereas future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals via the LISA space mission are expected to refine these bounds by several orders of magnitude.

Analyzing the evolution of graphs over time presents a significant challenge across various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social network analysis. A frequent scenario involves edges representing either short-term interactions (e.g., instant messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendships). In real-world applications, long-term edges are typically human-defined, which can be both costly to establish and suboptimal for subsequent tasks. To address these limitations, we introduce a model combining temporal point processes with variational autoencoders, designed to automatically infer temporal attention between nodes by analyzing their communication patterns. Since temporal attention governs feature propagation between nodes, learning this critical component from interaction dynamics offers greater adaptability while circumventing the drawbacks of manually specified edges.

We report observations of thermally induced transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW). The PCW comprises two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. We develop and validate models that transduce beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating through a guided mode (GM) of the PCW, both for probe frequencies far from and near the dielectric band edge. As our PCW was designed for near-field atom trapping, this study establishes a framework for assessing potential adverse effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near PCW surfaces. Our long-term objectives include achieving robust atom-mediated coupling between individual vibrational phonons and single photons propagating in the PCW's GMs, enabling quantum-level optomechanical interactions among atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors evaluated at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups in adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. These splittings are of particular interest in equivariant stable homotopy theory, since the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum constitute a global Mackey functor. Consequently, the splittings imply that certain long exact sequences of homotopy groups decompose into short exact sequences. In the cases of the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, these splittings further demonstrate the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects result in a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The insufficiently constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression represent a significant source of uncertainty for forthcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a two-part series, we employ simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its corresponding covariance matrix, both adjusted for baryonic effects using the baryonification approach of Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we develop an emulator to rapidly predict the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to conduct a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ΛCDM cosmology that incorporates both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in natural settings, such as those captured in child-centered recordings, are among the most challenging types of audio to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such diverse conditions would be highly valuable for language acquisition research, where understanding both the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce is crucial. Such models also hold promise for early diagnosis and assessing remediation outcomes. In this paper, we outline our approach to creating an open-source neural network designed to classify audio segments into four categories: vocalizations by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings across 10 languages.

Density-based clustering operates on the principle of associating groups with specific characteristics of the underlying data's probability distribution. By referencing the true (though unknown) population structure, this approach positions the clustering problem within a standard inferential framework, where the ideal population clustering is defined as the partition generated by the true density function. The nonparametric implementation of this method, termed modal clustering, establishes a connection between groups and the domains of attraction of the density's modes. Practically, this requires a nonparametric density estimate, and careful selection of the smoothing parameter—which influences both the density's shape and its modal structure—is essential for determining the final partition. In this study, we examine the challenge of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic standpoint.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC exhibit sensitivity to interference effects between Standard Model processes and higher-dimensional operators that parameterize heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules governing diboson scattering amplitudes create an obstruction to the naive interference contributions from dimension-six operators, leading to a cancellation of the leading-order correction to the total diboson production rate. Remarkably, precise measurements of azimuthal decay angles can "resurrect" this interference, thereby restoring sensitivity to these "non-interfering" operators. We conduct a detailed investigation of these signatures and demonstrate that the effective field theory (EFT) uncertainties related to higher-dimensional operators are exceptionally well-suppressed through the construction of an asymmetry variable. This observable is uniquely generated by the non-interfering operators, effectively reducing the impact of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the level of statistical uncertainties in this measurement.

Causal inference from observational data is a central objective in many health and social science studies. Yet, academic statistics has traditionally viewed causal analyses with skepticism. The emergence of "data science" presents a pivotal opportunity to reshape data analysis in a way that inherently supports causal inference from observational data. Following earlier frameworks, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three core tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). A clear taxonomy of these tasks is essential to examine the data requirements, assumptions, and analytical methods needed for each. We contend that neglecting to articulate the role of domain expertise in data analysis has led to widespread misconceptions about data science.

The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. Conventional understanding suggests that these particles are necessary to ensure extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, yet the consequences of violating this condition remain unclear. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously established quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. Resolving this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative formulation of the WGC, which simplifies to the standard statement at weak coupling. The argument is broadly applicable, independent of supersymmetry or specific UV completions, relying only on the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can lead to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains one of the most significant unresolved challenges in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have become ideal model systems—clean and highly controllable—for investigating the interplay between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. However, direct evidence of superfluidity in such systems has remained elusive. In this study, we observe superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and detecting the absence of dissipation below a critical velocity \(v_{\rm c}\). We measure \(v_{\rm c}\) across varying interaction strengths and identify a peak in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. These results firmly establish ultracold Fermi gases as a versatile platform for exploring the effects of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions composed of a time-reversal symmetry-broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) coupled to an $s$-wave superconductor. Our results demonstrate that both the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit a pronounced dependence on the angle between the junction's real-space orientation and the momentum-space axis separating the Weyl nodes. We further analyze the impact of a chiral chemical potential—representing the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—on the junction's transport behavior. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated through Andreev reflection in both WSM regions. This polarization is oppositely oriented in the two regions and exhibits strong sensitivity to both the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

The implantation of metal ions into ceramics has proven to be an effective and controllable method for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic components, with numerous practical applications. Notably, this technique enables the grading of voltage distribution across high-voltage insulators, thereby enhancing their maximum operational voltage capacity by preventing surface flashover. However, a key concern regarding this method is the long-term stability of the conductivity induced by implantation, particularly when the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. In this study, we investigate the long-term evolution of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Our findings reveal that, after an initial decline of up to 40% within the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity subsequently stabilizes, exhibiting only a gradual reduction of approximately 10% over the following year.

We present a novel Skyrme-like conserved current within the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in the framework of hidden local symmetry. The corresponding charge coincides with the Skyrmion charge for any smooth field configuration. Furthermore, singular configurations emerge that can be interpreted as \(n_f=1\) baryons carrying charge under this new symmetry. In this interpretation, the vector mesons effectively serve as Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the \(n_f=1\) baryon. We argue that this current represents the appropriate low-energy effective description of the baryon current. This perspective provides a unified framework for both types of baryons, enabling their natural continuous transformation into one another. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be understood as arising from a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a compelling approach to unify anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the interplay of these phenomena influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The spin-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates substantial transverse Hall supercurrents, which we term anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula—originally developed to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson currents—to assess the transverse current components, revealing that their amplitudes can be widely tuned via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of these Josephson junctions, tightly localized subgap bound states emerge near the interface.

Building on insights from Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul. 2020), which highlighted the equal importance of dipoles and individual vortex cores in decaying two-dimensional turbulence dynamics, this study reveals that the flow's kinetic energy is predominantly transported by elongated streams composed of interconnected dipoles. The vortices segregate into two distinct groups: a collection of compact, rapidly moving cores and a set of larger, quasi-stationary structures resembling a slowly evolving "crystal." These families exhibit markedly different kinematic behaviors, with only the former displaying self-similar characteristics. The latter group, which accounts for the majority of the flow's kinetic energy, forms both the dipoles and streams. The paper further examines potential mechanisms driving the development of this slower-moving component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have emerged as a highly effective framework for designing various quantum algorithms. Typically, the runtime of such algorithms is determined by the quantum hitting time—the duration needed for the quantum walk to locate a target vertex with high probability. In this work, we present refined upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to numerous continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithms. Specifically, we demonstrate the utility of our approach by enhancing the hitting time upper bound for the glued-trees problem, achieving a polynomial improvement from \(o(n^5)\) to \(o(n^2\log n)\). Additionally, our techniques yield an exponential improvement in the precision dependence for the continuous-time quantum walk algorithm developed by Chakraborty et al., which identifies marked nodes in any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously regarded as the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are mainly generated through multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we emphasize an alternative EMRI formation pathway: wet EMRIs facilitated by the accretion flow surrounding accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). Within this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits, then induces their migration toward the MBH—significantly enhancing the EMRI formation rate in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack any prior information about them—no item interactions, no user profile, and no social connections with other users. Despite this, we still expect our recommender systems to engage these users immediately, encouraging them to stay on the platform and become active participants. This challenge falls under the new user cold-start category, which is critical to a company's growth and even its long-term viability.  

Existing approaches to user cold-start recommendations either demand additional effort from users, such as completing an interview process, or rely on side information like demographics, location, or social ties [10]. However, users may be reluctant to undergo interviews, and such side information is often unavailable for cold-start users.

Deep learning has successfully addressed numerous challenges beyond the scope of heuristic algorithms. Its applications have extended to wireless communications, despite existing radio systems being well-understood with optimal algorithms available for many functions. While incremental improvements have been achieved by learning individual receiver components, a more effective strategy involves jointly optimizing the entire receiver system. This approach, however, typically leads to complex nonlinear optimization problems where ideal solutions prove impractical to implement. Addressing this challenge, we present deeprx—a fully convolutional neural network that processes the complete receiver chain from frequency-domain signal streams to uncoded bits while maintaining 5G compliance. To enhance channel estimation accuracy, we carefully design the CNN's input structure by strategically incorporating both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing generally begins with an initial set of valid seed inputs (a corpus) that are mutated to generate new test cases. Typically, such corpora contain numerous similar inputs, which can result in redundant fuzzing efforts when exhaustively mutating all available seeds. To mitigate this issue, modern fuzzers incorporate distillation tools (such as afl-cmin) that identify the minimal subset of seeds capable of exercising the same spectrum of code coverage as the complete corpus. Industry experience indicates that reducing both the quantity and total size of seeds enhances fuzzing efficiency—a hypothesis we methodically investigate. Our study presents findings from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing experiments using five distinct distillation techniques, evaluating their effectiveness in discovering vulnerabilities in production software.

This paper examines multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents can be categorized into multiple groups, where agents within each group possess similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Leveraging this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational complexity remain unaffected by the number of agents, even under partial observation. Notably, this scalable supervisor maintains its validity without recomputation, regardless of agent additions or removals from the system. We extend our previous findings to partial observation by establishing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An illustrative example demonstrates the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis approach.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. This paper introduces an efficient ENF estimation method using temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. Leveraging the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix, we employ a Gohberg-Semencul factorization for computational efficiency. Notably, this approach innovatively incorporates a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation—a first in ENF analysis. For rapid matrix inversion, Krylov matrices are utilized. The proposed method surpasses state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation, particularly for short 1-second time windows in power recordings. In speech recordings, it achieves superior accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency.

The **direpack** package is designed to introduce a collection of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem as a unified and cohesive toolkit. The included dimension reduction methods fall into three main categories: projection pursuit-based approaches, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, the package offers regularized regression estimators built upon these reduced-dimension spaces, spanning from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression.  

Beyond core functionality, **direpack** provides a suite of classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting tools and cross-validation support. Designed for seamless integration, the package adheres to the **scikit-learn** API, ensuring compatibility with statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely utilized for high-spatial-resolution optical imaging. In this study, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturation effect in nitrogen-vacancy defects within diamond. Under high-power laser excitation, we observed fluorescence reduction, which enhanced the nonlinearity of fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution in the fluorescence image. A differential excitation protocol was employed to extract high-spatial-frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser power, the imaging spatial resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of both the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate this method can enhance spatial resolution for sensing and biological labeling applications using solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with design variables in sample surveys, conventional methods that use individual survey weights (constructed as inverses of unit inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fail to yield asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that enables unbiased inference for hyperparameters governing these effects. Our approach is compared with frequentist methods dependent on numerical integration, demonstrating that only the Bayesian method achieves both design-unbiased estimation and consistency with the population-generating distribution. Through simulations and a real-world application involving business establishment surveys, we illustrate our method's effectiveness across diverse modeling frameworks and sampling designs. This research culminates recent advances integrating traditional survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, establishing a meaningful connection between these two rich yet distinct statistical domains.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—including ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, among others—exhibit more intricate atomic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The diminished symmetries of these emerging materials lead to nonuniform electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, enhanced nonlinear optical characteristics, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Additionally, low symmetry can induce unique electronic topological features, nonlinear elastic behaviors, and structural phase transitions. The *Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials* special topic was curated to showcase cutting-edge experimental and theoretical advancements in this field.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer featuring mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was observed that, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of electric birefringence in a mesogenic polymer melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a superposition of multiple exponential processes, with two of them being dominant. These primary relaxation mechanisms alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Additionally, dielectric spectroscopy revealed two distinct orientational relaxation processes: the first arising from the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second linked to the motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. A key challenge in these methods lies in optimizing discrete hash bits effectively. A prevalent approach involves using activation functions such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, coupled with minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this strategy risks trapping an increasing number of hash bits in the incorrect saturated regions of the activation functions, making recovery difficult—a phenomenon we term the "dead bits problem (DBP)." Moreover, existing quantization losses further exacerbate DBP. To address this issue, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied prior to activation functions, mitigating the impact of DBP.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by its role in two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. We examine scenarios where the triplet remains stable, potentially contributing to dark matter, or decays through mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The stable case is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, while the decaying scenario faces limits from existing multilepton collider searches. Our analysis shows that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is excluded by direct detection results. Additionally, an unstable triplet with a mass below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is ruled out at the $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). According to the conventional scenario, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis *a* acquires an eccentricity *e<sub>f</sub>* through secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after the gas disc dissipates, producing a belt of width *2ae<sub>f</sub>*. A slight variation of this model suggests that narrower belts may form if the planetesimals already possess some initial eccentricity, potentially induced by earlier planetary perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, such primordial eccentricity could arise from disc instabilities that elevate the disc's eccentricity independently, without requiring the presence of planets.

An electron is typically regarded as possessing only one form of kinetic energy, but might it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other excited electrons? In one-dimensional (1D) systems, the physics of interacting electrons is effectively described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, though experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. Our results reveal two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with the appearance of three supplementary 1D 'replica' modes that intensify as the wire length decreases. By adjusting the degree of 1D inter-subband screening, we modulate the effective interaction strength in the wires by more than 45%.

**Context.** The assembly history of the Milky Way is now being revealed through data from the *Gaia* mission. It is probable that our galaxy’s globular cluster system has undergone an equally complex formation process.  

**Aims.** To better understand this formation pathway, we investigate the connection between globular clusters and the Milky Way’s known merger events.  

**Methods.** For this purpose, we combined kinematic data from *Gaia*—covering nearly all galactic clusters—with the most extensive sample of cluster ages available, after meticulous corrections for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a shared origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, focusing on their integrals of motion.  

**Results.** Our findings indicate that approximately 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial preliminary step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces *intrinsic*, an R package that implements cutting-edge, likelihood-based estimators for determining a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package incorporates three methods: the *two-nn*, *gride*, and *hidalgo* models. To ensure these advanced estimators are user-friendly, the package provides high-level, intuitive functions supported by efficient low-level routines.  

The models in *intrinsic* are divided into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the *two-nn* and *gride* models, with dedicated functions supporting both frequentist and Bayesian inference. The second category features *hidalgo*, a Bayesian mixture model for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond timescale, showing promise for enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. In this study, two physical RC systems were proposed and modeled: one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another employing 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), designed for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks, respectively.  

Our micromagnetic simulations of the nonlinear responses in MSM and STNO devices under current pulse stimulation demonstrate that an RC system utilizing a single MSM achieves exceptional performance in handwritten digit recognition. Furthermore, a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs proves highly effective in solving complex, unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as validated through second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are pivotal in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper reveals an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: when fewer items report a particular signal, they collectively attract a larger share of overall traffic. This 'few-get-richer' effect arises in contexts with limited distinct item categories (e.g., left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources) where rankings are determined by popularity.  

Through analytical modeling, we show this effect emerges when users predominantly click top-ranked items while exhibiting diverse preferences across item categories. Simulations further explore how the effect's intensity varies with different assumptions about the environment and user behavior. We also validate our predictions experimentally via an online study with human participants. These findings offer significant insights for understanding the dissemination of misinformation.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective approach to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across diverse platforms. However, most existing pruning methods fundamentally compromise between model accuracy and structural regularity, often resulting in diminished inference accuracy and suboptimal on-device acceleration performance.  

To address this limitation, we propose a novel sparsity dimension called pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity to achieve both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. Through meticulously designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across various DNN architectures and datasets—an unprecedented achievement. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework seamlessly integrates pattern library extraction, pattern selection, as well as simultaneous pattern and connectivity pruning with weight training.  

This innovative pattern-based sparsity approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

A difference-in-differences analysis employing a control group that significantly differs from the treated group is susceptible to bias due to historical events affecting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the broader control group may reduce this bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. Specifically, we examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach, leveraging the increase in MRM activity following the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments. In our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a more precisely matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval encompassing substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is essential to assess their ability to accurately reproduce the original data. This evaluation can be performed using visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve three key steps: (1) generating multiple simulated replicates of the original study using the model being evaluated, (2) computing relevant estimates for each simulated dataset, and (3) comparing the distribution of these simulated estimates with those from the original study. This approach serves as a versatile and generally straightforward validation method. In this context, we specifically examine its application to time-to-event data, with particular attention to cases where time-varying covariates are either unknown or cannot be reasonably estimated after the event occurs.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We examine how analogous protocols, combining repeated quantum measurements with dynamical decoupling control pulses, enable: (i) the confinement and protection of quantum dynamics from decoherence, consistent with Zeno physics; (ii) the analytical prediction of quantum state transfer probabilities via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) the optimal reconstruction of environmental noise spectral densities by orthogonalizing frequency-domain filter functions in designed quantum sensors. Accomplishing these objectives will significantly improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technologies.

Your palms sweat, your heart races, and your stomach twists into knots. You can’t call for help—not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but the humiliation would be unbearable. No, you aren’t being hunted by a monster; you’re speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. After all, when you’re dead, you feel nothing—but at a podium, you feel every ounce of stage fright. Yet at some point, we’ve all had to address a crowd, so you must learn to push through it.  

Start by understanding stage fright. As social creatures, humans are hardwired to care about reputation, and public speaking puts yours on the line. Before a speech, your mind spirals: *What if they think I’m terrible? What if they see me as a fool?*

It’s rare to find someone with just one interest in life, content to pursue only that for the rest of their days. [The way we work] Approximately 15 percent of American workers don’t hold traditional full-time jobs—they’re part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" aligns perfectly with this ethos, capturing how people piece together multiple pursuits to earn a living.  

The phrase "side hustle" traces its origins to popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, "hustle" often referred to a scam, but by the 1950s, "side hustle" had evolved to include legitimate work. Unlike a second job, which is often driven by necessity, a side hustle reflects a more intentional and varied approach to making ends meet.

Two twin domes, two radically contrasting design philosophies. One is constructed from countless steel components, the other woven from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other natural. One imposes itself upon the environment, the other emerges from it. One is designed for nature, the other is nature’s own design.  

Michelangelo once remarked that within raw marble, he glimpsed a figure yearning to break free. His chisel was his sole instrument. Yet living beings are not carved—they evolve. Within our most fundamental units of life, our cells, lies the complete blueprint for every function and replication.  

Tools, too, leave their mark. Since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, the realm of design has been shaped by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You’ve probably heard the advice that if you’re nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked—supposedly to make you feel better. But honestly, imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels a bit odd and outdated. We’re trying to move past that kind of thinking, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. Here’s what occurred to me: I’d love to look at you just as much as you’re looking at me—to balance things out. So really, if I had a lot more eyeballs, we’d all be perfectly comfortable, wouldn’t we?

To attempt two things at once is to accomplish neither." This biting critique of multitasking—often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, though such attributions are notoriously unreliable—raises an intriguing question: Is it accurate? Certainly, it holds true for checking emails at dinner, texting while driving, or perhaps live-tweeting during a TED Talk. Yet I’d contend that for certain meaningful endeavors, pursuing two, three, or even four tasks simultaneously is precisely the ideal. Consider Albert Einstein: in 1905 alone, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better versions of ourselves. You see, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania—the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my childhood, he taught me how things worked. We often collaborated on projects, from model rockets to slot cars. This is the go-kart we built together—there I am behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. Then one evening, when I was around ten years old, my father came home and made an announcement at the dinner table: for our next project, we were going to build...a robot. A robot.

Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is harvested—but the who and why matter most to me. I want to know the individuals behind my meals, understand how my choices affect them, and how their lives intersect with mine. I want to learn why they fish and how they depend on the ocean’s abundance for their livelihood. Grasping these connections transforms seafood from a mere commodity into a chance to heal our ecosystems. It lets us appreciate the food we’re privileged to enjoy. So what do we name this? I believe we call it restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on endurance and preservation, restoration embodies renewal and advancement.

The starving orphan pleading for a second portion of gruel. The lonely spinster fading away in her threadbare wedding gown. The cold-hearted miser tormented by the specter of Christmas past. Even a century after his passing, these remain indelible figures from the works of Charles Dickens. So powerful is his literary legacy that it spawned its own descriptive term. Yet what distinguishes Dickens's writing as truly extraordinary? His fiction overflows with suspense, crafted through atmospheric settings, unexpected turns, and enigmatic plots. These signature elements left readers yearning for each new installment. Originally, his tales appeared in serialized form—published chapter by chapter in inexpensive periodicals before being compiled into volumes.

**Shah Rukh Khan:** Courage, determination, and an unwavering vision—these are the defining traits of history’s greatest achievers. These are the fearless souls for whom failure is never an option. What may seem to us like an insurmountable ocean is, to our next speaker, nothing more than the stage she was destined to command. So without further delay, let’s immerse ourselves in the inspiring journey of Bhakti Sharma, a trailblazer in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. *(Applause)*  

**Bhakti Sharma:** Picture this—a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan, where a two-and-a-half-year-old clings to her mother on a moped, oblivious to their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same child finds herself plunged into the depths of water, her life forever changed.

I'd like to discuss a groundbreaking technology currently under development at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize how computer games and Hollywood films are created. This innovation involves simulating humans - complete with virtual bodies and nervous systems to control them. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's briefly examine how human characters are currently portrayed in video games. Here's a clip from 'Grand Theft Auto 3,' which we glimpsed yesterday. While this is actually an excellent game - one of the most successful titles of all time - it demonstrates the current state of digital human representation.

Let me share with you a fascinating perspective on the future of money. Our story begins with the Yap people, a Micronesian culture from the early 1900s, whose unique monetary system offers valuable insights. What makes the Yap particularly interesting is their currency: massive limestone discs known as rai stones. Unlike modern coins that change hands physically, these stones often remain stationary due to their enormous size—some reaching up to four tons and twelve feet in diameter. Instead of moving them, the Yap maintain an intricate system of ownership records for portions of each stone. There's even a legendary account of sailors transporting one such stone across the ocean when disaster struck, causing it to sink beneath the waves.

You stand accused of a crime you did not commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and face execution. But if you confess, express remorse, and name others, you’ll walk free. Do you falsely confess—or risk the gallows?  

This was the grim reality for those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to supernatural paranoia, misguided religious zeal—and a justice system that prized repentance over truth.  

Founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants seeking religious purity, Salem was a place of rigid discipline and isolation. Conflicts with neighboring Native American tribes and French settlers were frequent, shaping a tense and fearful community.

Currently, hundreds of thousands of individuals remain on transplant lists, awaiting life-saving organs such as kidneys, hearts, and livers. Sadly, the supply of donor organs falls far short of meeting this urgent need. But what if, rather than waiting, we could engineer entirely new, personalized organs from the ground up? This is the vision driving bioprinting—an emerging field within regenerative medicine. While we cannot yet produce fully functional complex organs, we have already succeeded in fabricating simpler tissues, including blood vessels and nutrient-exchange conduits. Bioprinting operates on principles similar to 3D printing, building three-dimensional structures layer by layer—only instead of synthetic materials, it uses biological components.

Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'd like to discuss a phenomenon that can—and indeed already is—changing the world: the power of people. I'll begin with an anecdote, or for Monty Python enthusiasts among you, a sketch reminiscent of their style.  

Here's the scene: It's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a wager—you’ll gaze into a crystal ball and see the future, a future that will prove entirely accurate. But there’s a catch: you must share this vision with the world. Intrigued, you accept the bet and peer into the crystal ball. One hour later, you find yourself in the studio of a national television network, appearing on a flagship program, recounting what you’ve seen.

We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, then 23 years old, stands at the peak of his burgeoning career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small but vocal minority accuses him of appropriating others' musical work.  

Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *The Black Album*, crafting *The Grey Album*. This remix quickly becomes an online phenomenon, only to draw relentless cease-and-desist orders from The Beatles' label, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our intellectual property." Here, too, the work in question is a remix.

That’s a rather evident observation above. I began with that statement roughly twelve years ago, initially focusing on developing nations. Yet today, you’re gathered here from across the globe. Picture a map of your own country—you’d likely recognize that for every nation on Earth, you could mark small circles and note, 'These are areas where skilled teachers refuse to work.' Moreover, these very places often become sources of societal challenges. This presents a paradoxical dilemma: the educators we need most are the least willing to serve in these critical areas. In 1999, I launched an experiment in New Delhi—a modest initiative—to tackle this very issue.

Currently, the majority of refugees reside in urban areas rather than in refugee camps. We account for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. Given this reality, there is an urgent need for a paradigm shift and innovative approaches. Instead of squandering resources on building barriers, it would be far more effective to invest in programs that empower refugees to become self-sufficient. (Applause) While we are often forced to leave behind our material possessions, we retain our skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute meaningfully to their host countries.  

I was born in Bukavu, a city in South Kivu, within the Democratic Republic of Congo. As the fifth-born in a family of twelve children, my early experiences shaped my perspective on resilience and community.

I have two questions for you. First: Whose shoulders do you stand on? And second: What do you stand for? These are the questions I always open my poetry workshops with because, too often, poetry can feel like a relic—an art form reserved for old white men who seem as though they were born aged, like some Benjamin Button paradox. I pose these questions to my students, then share how I answer them—in three lines I return to like a refrain:  

*I am the daughter of Black writers,*  
*who are descended from freedom fighters*  
*who broke their chains and changed the world.*  

They call me.  

I whisper these words like a mantra before every poetry performance. Even today, I was murmuring them in the corner over there—making faces, lost in the rhythm.

*(Inhales deeply, exhales slowly)* So, I haven’t always made my living through music. For roughly five years after graduating from a respected liberal arts university, this was my daily routine. *(Chuckles)* I worked as a self-employed living statue—the "Eight-Foot Bride"—and I adore sharing this part of my past because, inevitably, people always wonder: *Who are these peculiar souls in real life?* *(Laughs softly)*  

Here’s how it went: I’d paint myself white, step onto a pedestal, place a hat or a can at my feet, and whenever someone dropped in a coin, I’d offer them a flower—along with a piercing gaze. And if they declined the flower? I’d linger with a wistful, longing gesture as they walked away.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and apprehension as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, humanity's first artificial satellite, into orbit. This modest metal sphere, measuring less than two feet in diameter, ignited an intense space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would span eighteen years and reshape global history. Though Sputnik marked a pivotal milestone, it was not technically the first human-made object to reach space. That distinction belongs to Germany's V-2 rocket, deployed in desperate missile strikes against Allied cities during the final stages of World War II. While militarily ineffective, this technology—along with the scientists who created it—was seized by both American and Soviet forces after the war, laying the foundation for their respective space programs.

I am a cultural omnivore whose daily commute is soundtracked by my trusty iPod—an iPod stocked with everything from Wagner and Mozart to pop diva Christina Aguilera, country crooner Josh Turner, gospel hip-hop artist Kirk Franklin, concertos, symphonies, and beyond. I’m also an insatiable reader, equally at home with Ian McEwan as I am with Stephanie Meyer—yes, I’ve even read the entire *Twilight* saga. And then there’s my home theater, where I indulge in a steady diet of DVDs, on-demand streaming, and binge-worthy TV. For me, it’s *Law & Order: SVU*, Tina Fey’s *30 Rock*, and the no-nonsense justice of *Judge Judy*—where "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.

Citizens of the world, we confront a global crisis of unparalleled magnitude. Please stand by for an urgent message from... the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres.  

The climate emergency represents the most critical challenge of our era. We are racing against time—and falling behind. Across the globe, frustration mounts, particularly among the youth, over insufficient action. Greater ambition is demanded from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals alike.  

That is why I welcome the launch of TED Countdown. Your innovation and influence can propel us toward a carbon-neutral world by 2050—our only path to preventing the most catastrophic effects of climate change. The solutions exist: we possess the science, the tools, and the means. Now, we must channel political will and collective energy to rise to this challenge.

Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—has been burdened by centuries of stigma, reduced to a topic many still discuss only in hushed tones. But why? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are menstruating. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "awkward" or even "shameful" subject to raise. From my own experience and the stories of women around me, I can tell you it’s exhausting. Exhausting to carefully retrieve a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, tuck it into your pocket mid-lecture, and slip away to the restroom as inconspicuously as possible. Exhausting to sit through classes or meetings, outwardly composed while silently enduring the agony of cramps.

The world's largest and most destructive environmental and industrial undertaking is located at the core of the planet's most extensive and pristine forest—Canada's boreal forest. Spanning northern Canada and extending into Labrador, this region shelters the world's last great wild caribou population: the George River herd, which once numbered around 400,000 animals. Though I failed to spot a single caribou during my visit, the antlers serve as tangible evidence of their presence. Throughout the boreal region, we're fortunate to host an extraordinary wealth of wetlands. Globally among the most threatened ecosystems, wetlands play a vital role—purifying air and water, storing significant quantities of greenhouse gases, and supporting an immense variety of wildlife.

Before the world of humankind came into being, there existed the divine realm of the gods—a land of sprawling fields, open plains, and lush gardens. Four brothers roamed this celestial domain, bound only by their kinship, for they knew no other family, not even their own parents. Among them, Deminan stood apart, his skin marred by painful scabs, and he often pondered why he alone bore this cruel affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended his gardens, Deminan and his brothers stole into Yaya's dwelling. After indulging in food and exploration, they discovered an enormous gourd suspended in the corner. But as they attempted to peer inside, the gourd slipped from their grasp.

Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. At a career fair on campus, I secured an interview with a startup called Theranos. Back then, there wasn’t much publicly available information about the company, but what little existed was genuinely impressive. Essentially, Theranos was developing a medical device capable of running a full blood panel using just a finger-stick sample. This innovation was compelling not only because it minimized the discomfort of traditional blood draws but also because it held the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

My journey to becoming a polar specialist—photographing and specializing in the polar regions—began when I was four years old, after my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived among the Inuit in a small community of just 200 people, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. In this remote setting, we had no television, computers, or even a telephone; radio was our sole connection to the outside world. I spent nearly all my time outdoors with the Inuit, learning through play. The snow and ice became my sandbox, and the Inuit, my teachers. It was there that my deep fascination with the polar world truly took root.

We are perceived as the institution that catches the fallout of failed social policies. I cannot determine who arrives at our doors or the duration of their stay. We receive those for whom every other solution has fallen short—individuals who have slipped through every remaining safety net. When other systems cannot manage them, we must. I'd like to take you on the remarkable journey of the Rosetta spacecraft—to guide and land this probe on a comet has been my passion for the past two years. To fully appreciate this mission, we must first understand something fundamental about the origins of our solar system.

Where does all the carbon we emit ultimately go? Carbon naturally cycles through ecosystems, existing in all living organisms, as well as in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and even deep within Earth's rocky layers. When plants and other organisms die, much of their stored carbon gradually returns to the atmosphere, where it can be reabsorbed by new plant growth. However, over geological timescales spanning millions of years, portions of this carbon—originally stored in ancient forests and marine life—transform into sedimentary rock or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. While natural processes such as volcanic activity release some of this sequestered carbon, human activities—particularly the combustion of fossil fuels—are now reintroducing vast quantities of this ancient carbon into the atmosphere. In fact, current human emissions exceed annual volcanic carbon releases by approximately sixtyfold.
